i think we are suing hostname differently

when i refer to a hostname change its genrealy means a change in hypervior_hostname
which may or may not result in a change of CONF.host.


for the libvirt driver they will be the same by defualt but may not be depending on the config.
Ack

by the way i think we both read/interpeted

"""The compute service will use this locally-persisted UUID to reliably find the ComputeNode record, and will check for a potential hostname (or CONF.host) change on startup. If such a rename is detected, nova-compute will fail to start and warn about the situation."""

in the  spec differntly

that is what i ment here

i read that as saying

will check for a potential hostname change or a potentail CONF.host change.

not impyting that a hostname change is equivalent to or impiles  a change in CONF.host

anyway i dont want you to get frustrated because we interpreed that section of the spec differntly.

also for context i interperted 

"will check for a potential hostname (or CONF.host)"

as implying the primary thing to detect was the hypervior_hostname change and that detectign the service host change via a change in CONF.host was secondary or of lesser imporance.

agreed on the cases.
MHO : 
- either the file is precreated by the operator before nova-compute service startup, and then we trust the file (the operator *has to* ensure the file content is relevant)
- or no file is precreated and then nova assumes to manage this file

Either way, if a file is missing after a non-upgrade restart, that means that both conditions are violated and we should prevent nova to blindly recreate a file since the assumptions would be incorrect.

Yep, as I've said, I think this is nova internal state, and just like we wouldn't expect nova to recover from deleting random stuff from the database, neither should be jump through hoops here. At least what I have here adds a "you have to lose two things to lose your identity" sort of backup.

yep we cant protect againt multiple pebkac issues

we can tollerate a rename or a file delteion/clobber but not both.
Then if operators are afraid of loosing such information, they should do some 3rd-party tooling for keeping persistence of such file contents.

Cool, but we also need to understand the limitations here. If you have both lost the node identity file *and* renamed the host, there's no way for nova to know that it's not a new never-before-started greenfield compute.
Ack

nova/compute/manager.py.message: nit: "we were started with a CONF.host value ..."

I need to test this (tomorrow), but I wonder if we can simplify all of this and say:

 - If we were started with a service ref and we are upgrading, we
   write our uuid out (once)
 - If we were started without a service ref, we are greenfield, so
   we generate and write a uuid (once)
 - Otherwise we fail because one of the two already happened and
   the file has been removed.
 
It doesn't cover the case where the file gets re-written with another random uuid by poorly-written ansible, but I still argue that randomly clobbering other persistent state is generally off the table anyway. Improving the error message we log when the name conflict happens in the RT would help make it clearer what happened there.

ah yes i see.
ya simple fix vs v5

ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands..message:
Ultimately used in lb_add_health_check, I don't actually see this called anywhere outside of test code:

https://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=lb_add_health_check&i=nope&literal=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=

This one looked a little concerning because [1] looks like it would expect a row, but python-ovs [2] just uses the row to convert to a uuid, and if it isn't row [3] just returns whatever we pass--which in this case is the UUID that would be expected to return. So given that it is passing functional tests, it *looks* safe. But given _row_to_uuid() is an internal function and isn't really documented with any guarantees as to behavior, it's at least theoretically possible it could break in a new release. But it should also be noted that that code has pretty much never changed.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp/src/commit/7733f0c5364de3805d7f8d5be429e0a464a7c6b1/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L876

[2] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/e85e8a7541cbe7d9c57bd34ae99d47edad92f111/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L1410

[3] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/e85e8a7541cbe7d9c57bd34ae99d47edad92f111/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L1187

I like this idea and I think this should be done. Do you think deleted rules should be kept indefinitely or would it be possible to specify a rotation policy to purge very old rules?

Hmm, we could create it as well in some future patch, but I think that even keeping all the rules for long periods, they number should not increase as much to start generating some performance/storage problems.
Agree, let's leave this for a later patch/blueprint.
What will decide whether the rule was used or not?

If it's start date is before the current date, it will be considered as used, I think it should be the simplest solution. Even in some cases that we just created a new rule using start as 1 minute in the future, then if we wait a few minutes, the rule start will be in the past, but the rating process was not started yet due the configured 'period', so we are considering a rule as used when it was not processed yet, but I think that it will make things simpler, not so accurate, but simpler :), What do you think?
Yes, this makes sense. Maybe add "(the start value is in the past)" here as well to clarify what the condition is?

I understand the rationale as it would be useful to have the ability to change historical data but I also feel this may end up causing problems when operators change the rule in the wrong period of time but didn't take a note of the original time. Maybe we should add a separate table only for keeping track of changes to dates or just not implement this part for now?

So will the history of updates be stored anywhere or only the UUID of the user who's chnaged the rule last time? My main concern here is the ability to rollback to old conditions if need be but I guess we can make keeping track of these a responsibility of the operator for now.

Not allowing users to simply update a rule, it will forces the user to delete the rule and create a new one with the new desired values, and, as we are not deleting rules anymore but marking them as deleted, we will know the deleted rule values, the user that deleted the rule and so on. To improve this behavior to users, they could create the new rule using the same name the old rule had, so it will ease to keep the track of the changes, and the history will be stored in the same table, just need to follow the deleted rules with the same name the rule you want to see the history, as well, if the name is not the same, you can track them using the 'service_id' or 'field_id' plus the 'value' in the rules definitions.

the update of rules will be allowed only for rules that not started yet (start is a future date), and for the rules that are already used, the only thing allowed to be updated is the end date (only if the end date is null, otherwise nothing will be allowed to be updated). We could also forbidden all kind of updates, so if the user wants to do any update, the one will need to delete and create a new rule, so is how the track will be handled without needs of new tables.
Sounds good.
Wouldn't it be better to use UUIDs to identify individual rules and let users name these whatever they want, even if the name is already used by a different rule?

The rules already have unique uuids, the unique names are more likely to allow operators to create some kind of information to make their rules unique, if they dont care about this field, they could generate random uuids to fill this field when creating the rules :).
*stay
Done

Is this the condition for determining whether the role was used or not?
Yes it is.
Excellent idea 👍
You actually propose three (also updated_by).
Missed that one, thanks 😊
What about recording all actions in another table, like Nova on instance events? This would allow us to keep a record of all updates instead of just the last one.

We could do that, but, with the current updating rules context, we are restricting the updating of rules to only a few conditions (the most of times, only updating the end date), so the number of rules recreation (deletion + creation) should be higher than the number of rules updates. And for the case of recreation, we are already tracking the rules in the mappings table, as we are not removing the rules anymore, but marking them as deleted. So what do you think? Would it be enough using this "recreate" approach? Or do you think that we would need this new table to handle the updating exceptions (updating roles where did not start yet)?
I would make the end date at 00:00:00 and use a strict comparison.

This default time for end date will be set only if the user does not send a date with time (timestamp), if the user sends it, then we are going to use it. For the case the user does not send the time and we set the time as 00:00:00, then the rule is going to end at the end of the specific day, but at the beginning of the day, and if we set it to next day midnight, the user could be confused - "I set the end day to 23/01/01 and it sets the end day to 24/01/01 00:00:00". 

So, basically here the desired behavior is that if the user does not set an end time, then it should be automatically set to the end of the day. What do you think?

Included steps as to how to reproduce the performance issue in a devstack

What basically you are doing is creating a nested query with the RBAC filters [1]. That means the DB needs to execute two queries instead of one.

Since [2], included in Yoga, we now include "target_project" ("target_tenant" before) and "action" as indexes of any RBAC table (not only "networkrbacs"). That means the query will filter by indexes (in both queries, with and without optimization).

I've created an environment with 500 networks created by a project and another 500 shared to it. These are the execution times with and without the optimization [3].

My -1 for this patch is because:
1) This optimization does not improves the performance.
2) Introduces an unneeded complexity in a code that is already difficult to understand.
3) The new query result of this optimization needs two nested queries instead of one. Unless it is proven that in a particular case this is better, I choose the single query code that also returns a more understandable and shorter SQL query.

[1]https://paste.opendev.org/show/bmN4cUhe0c8iT1CZzaPp/
[2]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/810072
[3]https://paste.opendev.org/show/brUC9JvrTOsy3suu5roQ/

Rodolfo, sorry for the delay.

I've been able to reproduce the issue on a Zed devstack built just a few weeks ago:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/bDlR7t4KIZsIEZA7hC5x/

My patch drastically improved the performance with only 1,000 projects and RBACs created in the devstack. Although the example uses 1,000... you can keep adding more and see that the API call wall time with my patch is unchanged regardless of how many RBACs there are, whereas the runtime without the patch gets exponentially worse as more and more RBACs are added.
Hello - I'd like to pull this PR out of abandoned status and drag it over the finish line. Are you requesting more documentation on the combinations of SQL expressions that can now be generated?

I believe that the performance issue *is* directly related to the SQL query. Looking at your paste, is it possible that you may have not noticed this because of the values chosen for all the variables? Note that the performance of the query is sensitive to the values used... if the anonymous inner query result set is small, then even the query without the patch will run quickly.

In order to demonstrate this, please look at my notes here where I leverage the slow query log to extract the exact slow query with all registers expanded to values:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/bzoeMpfkpZLvrXcHmAxW/

You can also just fork a ton of 'openstack network list' commands in the background without the patch applied and watch top -- you'll notice that the only process with any CPU time used is mysql.
Please, give me a reproducer to check that locally. For example, create a certain amount of networks, ports, etc and how many of them shared and how.

I've reproduced the environment described. Using the non-admin user, I was able to achieve the performance differences reported.

However this performance issue is not in the SQL query. Both queries [1] perform the same. The time consuming operation is the SQLalchemy construction of the Network DB objects, specifically when retrieving the RBAC registers. But this is not related to the queries themselves but to how SQLAlchemy caches the queries on a transaction. In your code, the RBAC entries are retrieved in a separate query and used later during the models_v2.Network DB object. That is what is speeding the CLI command.

I we agree to implement this, I would add an extensive documentation explaining:
- How the queries are build, including SQL examples.
- What is the rationale of this change, explaining what I've said before. Please, don't justify this patch saying that the new SQL query performs better. This is not true. Both queries, in my env, take around 5ms when executed via direct SQL call (using the mysql shell).

[1]https://paste.opendev.org/show/bmN4cUhe0c8iT1CZzaPp/

Rodolfo, thank you for your candid feedback.

I did test your proposed changes earlier with a copy of our databases in-house that exhibit the performance problem, and I could not observe any improvement (see comment #31 on https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1918145). But perhaps I messed up, or there have been more changes since; I'll give it another go and report back.

All the same -- I completely sympathize with the complexity of this PR. I dislike it. It's very messy and reduces the generality of the filters.

That all being said: if you also look at comment #32 in the same LP link that I pasted above, the difference this patch makes in our production clusters is simply jaw-dropping. We had queries taking tens of seconds to minutes in production that now take way 100s of ms at most. This PS unquestionably improves the performance of a specific case (where there are thousands of RBAC rules).

And sorry - my notes in the paste use the OS_USERNAME/etc. of admin, but you should run the `openstack network list` and equivalent commands *as the demo user* (provided via openrc) to perform a/b/a testing and observe the performance benefits.

just to clarify: is this for models that not relate to RBAC in any way?

Not necessarily - let's take an external network as an example. Of course, an external network has RBAC entries so that Neutron can delegate access to them. But, if we want to filter on some property of the external network, like segmentation_id, we would do so using a filter_hook and not a rbac_filter_hook, because we want to filter on the property of the model.

Given this - I see how this could be worded better. Reworded the text here.

Yes, filter_hook is for the model part of the query only, after the RBACs have been evaluated. rbac_filter_hook cannot use any of fields from the model part of the query because we do not evaluate it against the "outer" part of the query (anything that would not inner join with an RBAC).

Here's an example of something that remains a filter_hook:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/2a44898119ad6e9de63c242440549ff40c5feeb0/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L113

And here's an example of something that was formerly a filter_hook, but now needs to become an rbac_filter_hook:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/2a44898119ad6e9de63c242440549ff40c5feeb0/neutron/db/external_net_db.py#L40

They have to be kept separate, because they have to be applied against different parts of the result set at different times as it is in flight.
can be just '_prep_query' as it's unrelated to any hooks

nova-api-proxy/nova-api-proxy/nova_api_p.message: we probably want to track this down at the source, where its assigning the empty/None HTTP_ headers being added to the env

I agree.

While searching for some clues in the StarlingX repositories, I discovered that this same problem was found and solved in a similar fashion in starlingx/distributedcloud:

https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/distcloud/+/852185

According to the comments in this review, if we don't explicitly set these headers to an empty string, the `keystonemiddleware` will automatically inject them in the request with `NoneType` as their values (by default).

In Python 3's builtin `http` library these values cause the request to fail this check:

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/044fb4fb53594b37de8188cb36f3ba33ce2d617e/Lib/http/client.py#L1262

My understanding is the routes on the subcloud can be created in any order and both admin and mgmt routes can co-exist. However, the system controller-subcloud communications will only be done over admin route if configured.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'm unsure this can be backported. This is a feature, and adds an additional vendor interface. It doesn't directly allow navigation around the issue which spawned it as well, which I think re-enforces not backporting it. Happy to remove my -2 if we can figure out a viable justification.
fujitsu-irmc-recheck
fujitsu-irmc-recheck
recheck
recheck

Sorry. My explanation was not good and makes you misunderstand situation.

Part of code other than vendor passthru doesn't change protocol which iRMC driver uses to connect to iRMC firmware running on Fujitsu server. It just checks whether iRMC driver succeeds to access REST API which iRMC firmware host.

iRMC firmware incompatibility which this patch deals with is that, if version of iRMC firmware running on Fujitsu server is iRMC S6 2.00 or later, iRMC firmware denies HTTP access to REST API of firmware, but accepts HTTPS access. (Here S6 means 6th generation of iRMC firmware.)
If version of iRMC firmware running on Fujitsu server is earlier than 'iRMC S6 2.00', firmware accepts both HTTP and HTTPS access to REST API as before.

Part of code other than vendor passthru checks, during verifying, whether iRMC driver can access REST API iRMC firmware hosts and then
* if iRMC driver uses HTTP and access fails, it just tells operator "HTTP access fails. You should check driver_info. And as FYI, iRMC firmware stops support HTTP access since iRMC S6 2.00 or later". And state moves to enroll state.
* if iRMC driver uses HTTPS and access is denied, it just tells operator "HTTPS access fails. Check driver_info". And state moves to enroll state.
* if iRMC driver succeeds to access REST API, it moves to manageable state.

So part of code other than vendor passthru only adds verify step to check REST API access and warns operator if access fails. This doesn't affect already deployed baremetal node.

Intent of this patch is to resolve iRMC firmware incompatibility which doesn't allow HTTP access to REST API but HTTPS. To resolve this, we doesn't need vendor interface this backport patch adds.

Reason I created vendor interface in patch against master branch is, another patch which deals with another iRMC firmware incompatibility (IPMI is disabled by default) seems to need curent iRMC firmware version to determine IPMI/Redfish to be used.
However we chose try-fallback approach to resolve this IPMI-default-setting incompatibility.
So there is no need to backport vendor interface.

However I need part of logic of this backport content to deal with iRMC firmware HTTP incompatibility.
If I remove vendor interface part of code, is it possible to backport this?

I drop code related to vendor interface and modify doc and release note.
I think this patch is more backportable now.

There are also some
"called_with"
assertion methods on octavia/tests/unit/compute/drivers/test_nova_driver.py
(instead of assert_called_with)
Done
Looks good to me

doc/source/admin/drivers/irmc.rst.message:
That is an interesting gap. I guess I'd rephrase this, but re-reading it, it makes sense.

Honestly, I'd consider noting that first support is generally deprecated (At least, this is my impression from this change.) And, also note just the version after which it is no longer functional.

Yes, there is strange version gap between the ones supporting virtual floppy disk and the other not supporting. Virtual floppy disk functionality is, in general, deprecated in recent firmware version.

I'll tell just the iRMC firmware version, virtual floppy disk is deprecated.

ironic/drivers/modules/irmc/boot.py.message: I don't think this is the right change to make. Why cannot an ISO operate without the floppy disk? We use the Redfish driver in this mode quite successfully. Yes, you won't be able to inject kernel parameters, but they can just as well be pre-configured (Redfish, iDRAC-Redfish and iLO work this way).

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic/drivers/modules/irmc/boot.py.message: Continuity of process doesn't need to be forever moving forward. Especially since support for floppy devices has been rapidly disappearing over the past few years. The community's other options and enhanced direction are also viable, but it really comes down to what makes sense overall. Truthfully, if we ripped out all of the virtual floppy drive support, I'd personally be okay with it as long as we don't try to backport that change.

> Why cannot an ISO operate without the floppy disk? We use the Redfish driver in this mode quite successfully.
To maintain same behavior of iRMC driver against old iRMC firmware version, this patch uses virtual ISO & virtual floppy image to do virtual media boot when iRMC firmware supports virtual floppy disk.

> Yes, you won't be able to inject kernel parameters, but they can just as well be pre-configured 
Sorry. I'm not sure the point. You mean, it's better to not use virtual floppy because of community direction around virtual media?

The point I'm trying to make: you don't need a floppy to make a pre-created ISO to work. It looks like right now the driver will create a floppy disk and try to insert it. You're changing it to creating a new ISO from a kernel/ramdisk. There is the 3rd option: an ISO without a floppy disk. Just the ISO provided via deploy_iso/boot_iso.

How about "Fixes ``irmc`` hardware type support of virtual media boot where behavior of recent iRMC firmware is incompatible with."
Because support of virtual media in iRMC firmware isn't deprecated or removed but only virtual floppy functionality is deprecated and removed.

Can the detailed error messages be obtained? If syntax errors occur, promtool shows the detailed error messages on stderr. So please consider obtaining those messages from stderr and put them into exception messages if we can.
Fixed. Stderr can be large message, so just logging it.
Done

Please avoid using try clause without except clause.

Finally clause uses flag variable defined in try clause. I think deleting rule files should be triggered by exceptions raised from `_upload_rule` and `reload_prom_server` methods.

Moreover, `_upload_rule` method raises PrometheusPluginError if rule validation fails, but `reload_prom_server` does not have raise statement even if reload requests fail (situation such as syntax error of other rule files in target prometheus servers).

Therefore, I think the below seems to be better in this context:

```
        try:
            for info in target_list:
                self._upload_rule(
                    rule_group, info['host'], info['port'], info['user'],
                    info['password'], info['path'], pm_job.id)
            for uri in reload_list:
                self.reload_prom_server(context, uri)
        except (sol_ex.PrometheusPluginError, <Exception of reload>):

IMO, putting this `for` loop into `finally` is not intuitive, it makes developers think PM jobs will be deleted regardless of whether `update_rule` is succeeded or not. Besides that, in my understanding, this clean up code (i.e., `for` loop) should be executed whatever the error is. I'd like to suggest the following code.
What do you think?

```
try:
    ...
except Exception as e:
    for target in target_list:
        self._delete_rule(target['host'], target['port'],
            target['user'], target['password'], target['path'],
            pm_job.id)
    raise e
```

Or, if you want to distinguish a cause of errors, you have to output some messages to log when catching them, otherwise specifying types of errors at `except` doesn't work. In this case, making the clean up code a method would be better.

raise_for_status is inconvinient because caller of this module expects PrometheusPluginError in case of error.

This request is reload api of prometheus, it is not the query api you mentioned.
In the query api, below error code is defined and 400 and 422 are related to the request body. However reload api doesn't need request body. I think it is enough to consider 503 error code.

400 Bad Request
422 Unprocessable Entity
503 Service Unavailable

I don't think setting upper limit is good idea because http client may generate it's own error code other than above. (e.g when network unreachable or dns down)

>  the number of digits

-> the number of digits printed 

sorry.

I didn't mean raising an exception from `raise_for_status`.

My points are:
- Indicate status codes we expect explicitly (even through the other library like `requests.raise_for_status`)
- Use existing libraries/methods as possible (avoid reinventing the wheel)

For 6xx or above, it must not be returned (unless the Prometheus is compromised), so we can ignore such cases basically. I just hesitate to print it, just in case.

The first idea that came to my mind is like this.

```
        try:
            resp, _ = self.client.do_request(
                reload_uri, "PUT", context=context)
            resp.raise_for_status()
        except HTTPError as e:
            raise sol_ex.PrometheusPluginError(
                f"Reloading request to prometheus is failed: "
                f"{resp.status_code}.")
        except Exception as e:
            raise sol_ex.PrometheusPluginError(
                f"Reloading request to prometheus is failed") from e
```

Please kindly tell me, if I'm missing something.

I think introducing 6xx is impossible because
it should be huge impact among all internet services.

Even if 6xx is received for some reason,
it should not be treated as success now.
Because 6xx is not defined in http protocol,  
(https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt section 6.1.1)

If upper limit is applied. That would be as below code.
However, I feel this is redundant.

        if resp.status_code >= 400 and resp.status_code < 600:

        else:
            raise sol_ex.PrometheusPluginError(
                f"Reloading request to prometheus is failed: "
                f"{resp.status_code}.")
```

> However, I feel this is redundant. 

I think it's not redundant. The code should show what we assume as a status code clearly and it even doesn't reduce the readability. Also, if we leave this line as is, the number of digits is not limited that is not good habit in terms of security.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you please specify a use case or scenario where you require "output" key names?
Thanks for sharing

For example:
We have a Compute node with standard create and configure operations. We want to execute the configure operation, which reassigns the public address and returns the result in the "addr" variable (this can be a call to the bash function or a variable from ansible facts, depending on the implementation). The TOSCA orchestrator must track the states of the nodes, so the result from this variable must be put in the attribute of the corresponding node specified in outputs.

    tosca_server_example:
      type: tosca.nodes.Compute
      capabilities:
        host:
          properties:
            num_cpus: 1
            disk_size: 10 GiB
            mem_size: 1 GiB
        os:
          properties:
            architecture: x86_64
            type: cirros
            version: 0.4.0
      interfaces:
        Standard:
          create:
            implementation: operation-example.sh
          configure:
            implementation: ansible-operation-example.yaml
            outputs:
              addr: [ SELF, public_address ]

Or you can get examples from TOSCA Standard: "2.16.1 Example: setting output values to a node attribute" and "2.16.2 Example: setting output values to a capability attribute" in http://docs.oasis-open.org/tosca/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML/v1.3/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML-v1.3.html

I think there is a bug with only having python3-dev here. Some platforms set python3-dev to "" in the package map. I think this was because those platforms pulled in python3 and the equivalent of python3 dev via "python3". What this means is we'll stop installing python3 all together for those platforms?

Maybe either keep python3-dev as it was or switch to "python3" across the board and manipulate the package map to install python3-dev for python3 where necessary?

So I think the difference now is that Python3 is a requirement for all images coming out of DIB.  Several of the in-chroot tools are now python3 so all images will have python3.  This wasn't the case during the transition period where we had things like centos7 not having python3 for a while.

Got it. Part of me likes being explicit about python here because ansible will end up relying on it. And bootstrapping python3 on our nodes without it being there using ansible is painful. That said simplifying is nice too and I'm happy to land this for that reason.

fixed issue that prevented you from listing roles by domain
this refers to the command ...
client.roles.list(domain=<str|Domain>)

this command is trying to be 2 things at once: listing roles and listing role grants. The role-grant feature uses the domain parameter as it should, but for the case of listing roles, the domain parameter was not forwarded to the super list method

the result was this behavior:
client.roles.list(domain=...) returned global-scoped roles instead of domain scoped roles

By forwarding the domain to that one line, this unexpected behavior is resolved

I think the Nova reference is misleading here, because I'm pretty sure the Nova solution does the filtering on upload (i.e., the offending properties are stored in the instance's image metadata, but aren't copied when a user requests a snapshot of that instance).  Your solution in this patch excludes the properties on download (i.e., cinder will never store them in the first place).

Just to clarify what my understanding was of Brian's suggestion, and therefore better contextualize my response, I am in favor of not deleting the metadata when creating volumes, just when performing operations that would break it (such as upload-to-glance). Given that it has already been coded the filtering of metadata when volumes are created, we can move forward as-is, as I don't really mind it and the metadata is useless to Cinder, or we could decide to remove it without much effort. Either way, not much effort is needed, but we need to decide what is best.

It is not misleading. It is a similar approach (similar!=same!=equal). I used the idea of filtering they applied there. I am not doing the same as they do in Nova. 

We can remove this sentence, if you think it is important to remove it though.

We can discuss this at the weekly cinder meeting tomorrow, but my opinion is that saving the image properties is important because some of them are actionable, and they can be changed on the image record in Glance.  For example, I create a volume V1 from image 1 at time t that has the image property cinder_img_volume_type=Fred.  Volume V1 is created with volume_type Fred.  At time t+1, the image owner removes the 'cinder_img_volume_type' property from the image.  At time t+2, I create a volume V2 from image 1, but this one has volume_type DEFAULT.  I call support and ask WTF.  Without a record of what the image properties were at the time V1 was created, this will be difficult to troubleshoot.

So I think we should do what nova does here and filter out properties on upload, even the os_glance ones.

A few questions about this.

- Why filter on download?  Are we sure that there's no utility to having these properties as part of the volume image metadata?  Since the problem is that Glance won't let you create an image with these properties, why not filter them out on upload as Nova does?

- Note that Nova didn't set a config opt for this, it's hard-coded, and in fact, Nova added a hard-coded list of absolutely-non-inheritable-image-properties in addition to Nova's legacy noninheritable_image_properties config opt.  The idea was to avoid mis-configuration of the opt that could lead to problems.  I don't object to this config opt (I think it could be useful), but I wonder whether we should also have the hard-coded list too?

I agree that the config option is definitely needed.  My question is whether we should *additionally* have the hard-coded list (to keep the similarity to the nova solution!).  I don't have a strong opinion on this; the issue is that Glance will *never* allow users to set properties in the 'os_glance' namespace, so if operators remove it by mistake when setting the config option, they will break all upload-volume-to-image calls.  Which they should notice and fix fairly quickly, but we could avoid this situation entirely with the additional hard-coded list.  Or we could simply point out in the help text for the option that you should only add stuff to the list, you shouldn't remove anything.

1) I am personally unaware of any situation other than upload-back-to-glance where this causes problems, despite the release notes stating that the metadata could cause problems on several interactions with glance. But indeed if only the upload-back-to-glance causes problems, I see no benefit in adding extra code to not save the metadata, aside from the fact that the metadata in question is generally useless to cinder.

2) I personally prefer having the config option because it allows the behavior to be configurable, it is not clear to me the need to add more hardcoded filter properties.
+1 for help text that os_glance shouldn't be removed

We need the config option (not just the hard-coded list) because glance property protections leave the possibility that an operator has configured read-only image properties in glance, and if so, they can use the option in cinder so that cinder doesn't try to write them when creating an image in glance.
```

English is not my mother language; therefore, I might have misunderstood it. That is why I created this option. Any alternative is fine by me. You guys just need to decide what you prefer.

I think this is inaccurate in a few ways.  Maybe something more like this:

  List of reserved image namespaces that should be filtered out when uploading
  a volume as an image.  When a volume is created from an image, cinder stores
  the image properties as volume image_metadata, and if that volume is later
  uploaded as a image, cinder will add these properties when it creates the image
  in glance.  This can cause problems for image_metadata that are in namespaces
  that glance reserves for itself, or when properties (such as an image
  signature) cannot apply to the new image, or when an operator has configured
  glance property protections to make some image properties read-only.  Cinder
  will *always* filter out image_metadata in the namespaces 'os_glance' and
  'img_signature'; this configuration option allows you to specify *additional*
  namespaces to be excluded.

Just to amplify Rajat's comment: the cinder release note guidelines are here:
https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html

A few things to keep in mind:

- in the 'fixes' section, please use the "Bug #1945500: Fixed whatever" format.  Since there will be a link to the bug, you don't need to mention the particular glance properties, but can instead say something like "Glance reserves image properties in the namespace 'os_glance' for its own use and will not allow images to be created with these properties.  This fix introduces a configuration option, xxx, that enables operators to specify a list of image property namespaces that will not be included when Cinder is requested to upload a volume as an image.  The default value is ``['os_glance']``.

- the config opt should be mentioned in the 'fixes' section, but also again in the 'upgrade' section.  You can repeat most of the info, just reword it slightly to put the emphasis on the config opt.

- i think you need to say "filter by namespace", because nova has 2 different options, one that allows a namespace filter, and one that allows a list of particular image properties, so we want operators to be clear about what this fix does.

- you say that image properties are filtered, but you don't tell people what to expect, that is, is it being done on download, so that these properties are never stored in the volume_image_metadata, or is it being done on upload (the properties are stored in cinder, but they won't be created in glance if you do an upload-volume-as-image action).

I believe you missed removing this

disregard this, it was an old draft.
Maybe add something like "This option is useful when an operator wants to use the Glance property protections feature to make some image properties read-only."

I suggest changing this to something like:

  Additionally, there are image properties, such as those associated with image signature verification, that are stored in a volume's image metadata, but which don't make sense to add to a new image when a volume is being uploaded as an image.  Thus Cinder will no longer include any volume image metadata in the namespaces ``os_glance`` and ``img_signature`` when it creates an image in Glance.  Because the Glance property protections feature allows an operator to configure specific image properties as read-only, this fix adds a configuration option, ``reserved_image_namespaces``, that allows an operator to exclude additional image properties by namespace (the ``os_glance`` and ``img_signature`` namespaces are *always* excluded).

Thanks for the quick response - See me comments inline.

I certainly would love to discuss this idea, spec and potential implementation during a weekly meeting or PTG if there are any happening (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Designate).

I ran into it when I dove into the issue of "resilvering" a secondary server (BIND9) with all the domains it should know about (see my post to the ML https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-May/028484.html).

Once you know what to search for, as in the terms "catalog domain", it seems quite widespread already and to have received quite some traction among DNS servers implementation in order to be able to use catalog zones for their provisioning. If you look at my referenced implementations it seems that all "relevant" DNS servers mention it in some way or other and BIND9 and Knot do have this feature for a while now. 

While not actually heling my point ... if you look at e.g. https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/NSDCatZ/ or https://github.com/PowerDNS/powercatz/ there also is potential to use catalog zones on servers not natively supporting them, yet. With data transfer and happening only via DNS this is much less complex as in doing API queries and pagination to Designate.

Not to become too philosophical, but to me the success of an interface or process depends certainly on its quality first. But also on the adoptions on both ends.

My point is that with BIND9 and Knot supporting being a client / consumer in their production code, that is a good reason to start supporting this in Designate as a provider / primary server.

First of all the issue with large deployments (lots of zones) is that some admin tool (rndc addzone/modzone in the case of BIND) is called on all secondaries - individually for each zone (see https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/src/commit/5d5d83e511acbf5d6f34e9a998ff16d96c5bb162/designate/backend/impl_bind9.py#L152). 

The catalog zone on the contrary will "just" be a list that the secondary can slurp in (after being notified about it) and do so in one go internally. The zone transfers for each domain from the mini DNS will then happen just like as they are now. So in essence this is about getting the zones setup / removed on the secondaries efficiently.

So regarding IXFR, are you mean for the catalog zone itself? Well I doubt that there is an immediate scaling issue there - but frankly mdns does not support IXFR any zone, see this comment in the handler: https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/src/commit/0b162a4c48ff7806ee0dda0f871a884a32374ed9/designate/mdns/handler.py#L69

specs/antelope/catalog-zones.rst.message:
I'd like to argue that while a catalog zone is technically a regular DNS zone, it's not a zone that belongs to a tenant (as you write down below). It's more of a technical vehicle to transport the list of zones. As such, maybe it would be feasible to avoid storing and maintaining it as a "regular" (new type "CATALOG") zone and treat it more like something "virtual zone", derived from existing data, instead of maintaining this somehow redundant data as zone:

 a) To enable providing a catalog zone for a pool all you need is the info that and how the zone should be presented (FQDN, TSIG, ...) all of that will be part of the pool (as you wrote in `Other Changes`).

 b) Then there is the "Schema Version" - maybe something that should go into yet another config setting of the pool? This would allow running pools with different schemas, and upgrade one by one ... when there are new schemas and Designate implements them. Via this setting only supported versions could be accepted when the pool is created or configured.

 c) Next is the list of zones belonging to a pool and which need to be returned - that's just one SQL SELECT to the zones table away.
 
 d) Finally we need a serial for the catalog zone and that has to reflect / update on changes to the zones of a pool. Here I'd like to imagine that using someting the lines of "SELECT MAX("updated_at") FROM zones WHERE pool_id = $MY_POOL_ID" (including deleted zones) should be sufficient.
 
 
 
My main arguments against the new zone type is 

a) the redundancy of the data and
b) the requirement to restrict API operations to this kind of zone, even for admins, as it is maintained by Designate internally.

Hi Christian, thank you for your comments.

Just to clarify, I am not advocating maintaining recordsets in the catalog zones. As you have mentioned, I think the content of this zone can be generated based on a SQL query (as I highlighted in Storage Changes #4).

Let me address the additional comments by there section identifier:

a) Yes, there is some information that defines a catalog zone that will be loaded from the pool.yaml and stored in the pool_attributes table (which I missed in the current spec draft storage section, Opps). However, I think it is in our best interest to still create a zone record for these catalog zones. I think some of the existing fields we track for zone are applicable to catalog zones and the management/debugging of them. For example, it will be much more straight forward to debug a missing zone transfer if the operator can make a familiar "zone show" call to find the current expected serial number of the zone. It will also simplify the work required to share these zones via the mini-dns and for the worker to properly handle NOTIFY messages. Given the current code base, by maintaining a zone record for these catalog zones, you will get some of this functionality for free. Along the troubleshooting lines, we also see folks that have modified the pools.yaml but forgot to run the update command. By having the catalog zones as part of the zone show/list APIs it makes debugging these situations much more simple. Finally, the other thing to note is that the cross-process/instance locking used in designate is based on the zone ID. By not having a zone record, there could be situations where catalog zone actions could result in inconsistent/unexpected results.

b) The "schema version" is the schema of the catalog zone being sent by mini-dns, so it is not a config setting that should be included in the pool definition, but generated by the catalog zone render code. I was suggesting managing it in the zone record for coding simplicity sake and for providing a query-able value via the API.

c) Correct, I tried to capture that in Storage Changes #4. Frankly, my hope is that a catalog zone transfer request would only trigger a single database query/round trip to collect all of the required data. I do however expect this query to be fairly complicated.

d) It would work to calculate the MAX() of the created_at, updated_at, and deleted_ad from the zones, but this could be a complicated query for requests like "list zones". It also raises race condition issues with the serial number and updates that are faster than a second. We have an open patch we are discussing around moving the serial number update to a batch model[1] to help resolve this issue. Again, this may be an area where if we treat these like any other zone we are handling, it may simplify the development of the feature and reduce future issues.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/designate/+/823325

>  d) Finally we need a serial for the catalog zone and that has to reflect / update on changes to the zones of a pool. Here I'd like to imagine that using someting the lines of "SELECT MAX("updated_at") FROM zones WHERE pool_id = $MY_POOL_ID" (including deleted zones) should be sufficient.

Reading this again, I believe the updated_at field is not working in this case ..
It's rather the larger one of MAX(created_at) and MAX(deleted_at), right? So the "serial" of the catalog is the last time a zone was either deleted or created for that particular pool.

Hi, comment by section.

a) Yes, "Storage Changes" section 5 and "Other Changes" section 1 talk to the new settings required in pools.yaml that will be loaded at pools update time. So, the same pools.yaml update process, but with optional additional config settings to enable a catalog zone for the pool. I will post a spin with the added pool_attributes update I missed in the last draft.

b) To clarify, this schema version is for the catalog zone format[1] and not related to the pools.yaml. Currently the only valid version is "2" per the catalog zone spec. From a Designate perspective, this value would only change if the code that renders the catalog zone is changed to support a new RFC schema version (I.e. what TXT records are required/available, etc.). So, frankly, this could be a constant value for now that would be included in the catalog zone (per the spec) and display for convenience in the zone record. The version field of a zone record must have a value in the database, so I was proposing to use the catalog zone schema version to meet that requirement. If/when another schema is defined, this could can be updated to support multiple schema as needed, potentially per pool if different backends support different schema versions. For simplicity here, I think we can just use "2" for now and address the additional functionality in a future patch.

d) The serial number topic is a complicated one, with multiple proposals as you have commented. I think for this spec I don't want it to get hung up on those parallel discussions. My proposal is we implement the current "naive increment" mechanism used for zone serial numbers. We would increment and send a notify for the catalog zone using the same mechanisms we do for the zone itself. This would trigger on zone create/update/delete. I will add a section in the spec for this as well. This would defer a better serial mechanism to a future patch once we agree on the best approach. The good news is catalog zones are not as likely to change as fast as zones with recordsets.

[1] https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-dnsop-dns-catalog-zones-08.html#section-4.3.1
Ah, d) is already discussed in the "Central Changes" section, item #2.

Sorry Michael, I did not mean to just reply with Ack ... responding to you by section:

a) I am convinced having the catalog being a zone in the database seems to make sense. So you are proposing to just use the established mechanisms for injecting and updating https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/admin/multiple-pools.html#pools-configuration for all required workflows to update any of the settings then?

Will you be updating the storage section of the draft accordingly?


b) My argument was rather to allow for multiple schemas to be supported at the same time, which would then require this to be configurable and per-pool. But maybe that is overkill to anticipate people to run different schemas among their pools and secondaries. But maybe a global config setting (which can always be added to Designate later) to allow sectting the schema version the renderer produces makes sense?

c) -

d) Good points. We also ran into issues with inconsistent serial numbers due to the time being used. The change towards a batch mode (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/designate/+/823325) looks promising. There is a long standing change to do increments instead of using the timestamp (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/designate/+/776173), maybe that is obsolete then? In any case the current zone serial code seems racy. Even a single Designate instance already requires coordination, see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/designate/+/776173/comments/29f20aba_7e006d1e, to coordinate the workers or whatever.

Back to catalog zones though: How would the serial of the catalog update then? With the new batch mechanism, could the producer receive some code to increment the catalog zone serial on every relevant action: creation and deletion of zones?

specs/zed/catalog-zones.rst.message: Nit: Please keep lines wrapped to a maximum of 80 chars, better 72, makes for easier reading and editing.
hopefully fixed with new patchset.

From the refs given, I'm not sure that any change is needed at all, because the zone should look like any other zone to Designate, or am I missing something? So this needs to include more detail about what actually should change.
Ack

I believe we misunderstood. 

I propose for Designate to be able to PROVIDE a catalog zone with all of the zones to allow efficient provisioning of secondaries / backends in the configured pools such as BIND9 via AXFR - not about providing this as a "feature" to users or their zones.

Catalog zones completely remove the requirement to actively add zones with those implementations that support consuming them in order to know the zones they shall serve.

At least from a quick look at the source, would require some additional logic in the handler (https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/src/commit/d05232fc075ffe6bfaf7a537334fe081bb41a65c/designate/mdns/handler.py#L201) to render this type of zone.
Yeah, this is quite considerate change to the miniDNS. It will have to know how to create/render the catalog zones based on the list of created zones.
Seems you dropped the "Alternatives" section. You should explain why it is not a valid option to handle this in the nameserver setup outside of Designate.

From an architecture point of view Designate is the primary / master for the DNS zones as the data (zones and records) is created here. All I am proposing is to provide the list of all zones via a catalog zone / in a certain format.

And yes the secondary servers would then simply needs a few lines of config to make use of this and there would be no active zone "add" and "delete" required anymore.

There really is no alternative. You either provide a the list of zones in the documented and supported catalog zone format or not. Being able to fetch the list of zones via the API already and then creating such a zone externally from Designate solely beats the purpose.
Would you also intend to supply the implementation for this spec? Without an assignee this spec will just collect dust.
Yes.

FYI, OpenStack in general has moved away from doing blueprint tracking and has focused more on specs for new features.
So, you don't need to worry too much about updating the blueprint. Hopefully that will save you some time/work.
I probably need to update the spec template boilerplate in this repo.

The critical part is getting a detailed spec that everyone agrees on.

Done. I used a mixture of the last spec and the template and went "with the flow".
I will add all sections of the current template. Sorry about the confusion, but I never intended to leave any important sections out of the spec.
Depending on the TTL of the catalog zones, the proactive approach Designate uses today may be faster.

Isn't "fast propagation" exactly what the NOTIFY mechanism / message (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1996) is all about? Letting secondaries know they should update their zone data? In the case of catalog zones the master only needs to notify the secondaries about that single zone, secondaries can then AXFR whatever they require.

As a fallback an additional safety net the catalog zone should obviously have a lower REFRESH time in its SOA than the default of 3600 seconds (24 hrs) - see my remarks on additional config parameters to the pools, this should be one of them, defaulting to a sensible value.

Can we update this with the current document, the one linked is deprecated.

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-dnsop-dns-catalog-zones/
Ack

It's a bit risky to implement against an ID as opposed to an RFC. At the ID phase it is more likely that structure and functionality can change.
I think the fact that a number of our backends already support it is a good sign.
Ack
Same comment here, I think there are situations where the proactive approach may be faster.

First of the catalog zone is clearly intended to implement the upcoming standard for managing fleets of secondaries. This spec only proposes to add this as an additional way for Designate to integrate with backends. An operator clearly has the choice to use drivers and proactive provisioning via those still.

As for the performance comparison of the two approaches:

I'd argue that the active (push provisioning) approach does allow Designate to do an explicit call of e.g. "rndc addzone" and does know when this has happened. But with all the events + RPC + call of the binary on each secondary happening, is this really faster or even more robust than just updating a zone and pushing out a NOTIFY to the secondaries?

If I may quite bluntly just quote the BIND9 documentation at https://bind9.readthedocs.io/en/v9_16_7/advanced.html#principle-of-operation:

```
5.14.1. Principle of Operation

Normally, if a zone is to be served by a secondary server, the named.conf file on the server must list the zone, or the zone must be added using rndc addzone. In environments with a large number of secondary servers, and/or where the zones being served are changing frequently, the overhead involved in maintaining consistent zone configuration on all the secondary servers can be significant.

A catalog zone is a way to ease this administrative burden: it is a DNS zone that lists member zones that should be served by secondary servers. When a secondary server receives an update to the catalog zone, it adds, removes, or reconfigures member zones based on the data received.
```

To me the approach of only providing the data in a catalog zone and then sending out a notification is much more lightweight Designate or any other controller centrally providing DNS data. Image not just a single zone being added, but having e.g. a new server added to the secondaries which needs to have all the zones added. If I may point you to my post on the ML (https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-May/028484.html) about secondaries getting "out of sync" or being "cold started" with the list of domains / zones.

Yes, one can do a reconciliation via "designate-manage pool update". But this needs to be done for each and EVERY zone. This clearly does not scale well. Depending on the DNS implementation on the backend, it's likely much more efficient to use the built-in and more and more standardized mechanism to add a ton of zones, than to have hundreds or thousands of binary calls via some admin tool.

Last but not least, when a user adds a zone or records Designate still has all the capabilities to check the backends have converged prior to changing a zone or record status from PENDING to ACTIVE.
Actually, just one "designate-manage pool update" will update all of the zones, so it does not need to be called for every zone.

This is actually not how I meant the "each and every zone" part. 

I was more about the need for the worker to use the rndc binary at least once for each and every zone - https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/src/commit/5d5d83e511acbf5d6f34e9a998ff16d96c5bb162/designate/backend/impl_bind9.py#L152 to have them all reconciled / ensure to be synced.

With a catalog zone this can be done via NOTIFY and the bind9 slaves doing an AXFR of the catalog, if the "catalog" feature is switch on for a particular pool.

Wouldn't Designate still need to setup the catalog zone on the secondaries to set it up to start syncing? This would still require a dedicated driver for the backend.
The other concern is each zone will need a TSIG key loaded on the secondary, prior to establishing the catalog zone. This is needed to make sure the zone transfers are authentic. Per the ID, only the key identifier can (and should) be published in the catalog, so those keys will still need to be pre-loaded.

Good point. Quite honestly Designate could just leave this to the operator to configure in their secondaries config. Catalog zones offer such a big chance to make the whole management of secondaries so much more lightweight to Designate.

There certainly could be some config snippet to explain what needs to be configured like here for BIND9 and the auth to use RNDC: https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/admin/backends/bind9.html

But with catalog zones hopefully being a standardized approach, this should not be anything Designate needs to actively care about, adding must more code to maintain.

We should discuss here if we see a need for the Change of Ownership (coo) property in the Designate implementation.
I'm not sure I see an immediate need.

No doubt this is still a moving target, but in my impression moving quickly towards a first RFC and therefore I want for Designate and my little farm of BIND9 secondaries to be part of it.


As for the COO (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-dnsop-dns-catalog-zones#section-4.4.1), I believe this mostly affects Designate when using multiple server pools:

>   The coo property facilitates controlled migration of a member zone
>   from one catalog to another.

I am trying to understand what the initial cause of such a "change" is? A transfer of the domain ownership to another entity? Do you see this being used in case of zone transfers between projects (via https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/dns/#create-zone-transfer-request)?
Could you elaborate a little more on what you refer to by "Change of Ownership (coo)"?

Page 7 of the Internet Draft (ID) talks about zone Change of Ownership (coo).
We should also comment on the implications of Groups (group property) for Designate. I.e. Views/ACLs would likely need this.
The serial property was removed in the last draft. The draft is definitely a moving target until this hits the RFC stage.
This sentence is a little hard to follow, but yes, this would have to be setup per-pool so that the right zones end up on the right servers.

Please leave in all of the sections of the template so we can comment on those other sections if we see additions. It's ok to have them just say "None", but it gives us an anchor point for comments.
Specifically we are missing "storage" and "other" sections here.
Ack

Storage, we will at least need to expand the pools yaml definition to indicate that a pool should have catalog zones configured on them. This would also be an indicator to the worker that individual zone creation would not be required for the pool.
Ack

Other:
We need to describe the security stance for the catalog zone.
There are security considerations about having a queriable list of all of the zones hosted in the pool.
We need to talk about TSIG configuration for the catalog zones.
We need to talk about ACLs such that not everyone can query the catalog zone.

> Other:
> We need to describe the security stance for the catalog zone.
> There are security considerations about having a queriable list of all of the zones hosted in the pool.
> We need to talk about TSIG configuration for the catalog zones.
> We need to talk about ACLs such that not everyone can query the catalog zone.

Good points, thanks!

Doing any sort of protection or filtering of catalog zones on source IPs or other arbitrary info to me is out of scope for Designate. https://kb.isc.org/docs/aa-01401 clearly states that production setups should make use of TSIG to protect catalog zones, that totally follows the "DNS-only" approach of catalog zones.

So yes, a configurable value for the TSIG key of a catalog zone is required.

I totally agree TSIG to protect access to the catalog is the way to go.
But isn't this already implemented for (other) AXFRs, see https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/search?q=query_enforce_tsig

If the catalog zone relates to a pool, as in it provides the list of zones a pool is responsible for, why not use the existing scope "pool" for TSIG keys?
* https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/dns/?expanded=create-tsigkeys-detail#id136

The handler also already checks the scope - https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/src/commit/d05232fc075ffe6bfaf7a537334fe081bb41a65c/designate/mdns/handler.py#L192

Any a catalog zone should "require" a pool scoped TSIG, as this is the amount / scope of data returned ...

So at a minimum the pools configuration would need to be extended to define a "catalog zone" TSIG.
However I am still concerned that we are not addressing the ability to restrict queries to the catalog zone.
This is called out in the ID:
It is RECOMMENDED to limit the systems able to query these zones.

I am not proposing "non-DNS" mechanisms as you imply, but using existing means to control access to this catalog data.

I.e. miniDNS would require a valid TSIG to allow the axfr. It could also deny any query to the catalog zone without the TSIG.
The alternative is to continue to have the worker process create the zones. Right?
Yes, this was a bit lost in translation. I meant to one either adds this as additional option or not. I shall rephrase this though.
This is duplicate, we should go back to the template format that contains the other required sections (work items, upgrade implications, etc.).
Ack

This needs to be expanded as central will need to be updated (maybe a new backend driver created) to send the NOTIFY for the catalog zone when a new zone is created. It will also need to be pool-catalog zone aware.

I am assuming here that there will be a "catalog zone" per designate "pool".
We need to describe how that mapping will be done.

I think we will need to define a new backend driver for this. We would also need to document the pool configuration settings for this driver.
Much like the bind definition:
https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/admin/backends/bind9.html

I think there are two clear alternatives that could be documented here:
1. Use the exist methods for zone management via the backend drivers.

I disagree that there is no alternative. We are doing zone management today via an alternative mechanism.

bin/swift-bench.message:
Doesn't this break normal behaviour?

By default there will be an options.container_name that's loaded in from the config or DEFAULT config values which is using UUID.

Adding it to the CLI is great, as this will override the config value.
Look on line 164, when options.num_container is 1, the container_name will be "<options.container_name>_1".
So it's not really container_name but container_name base.

So I think you need to remove this check as it isn't required. and change the help string to in line 121 to say something like:

  Set the base container_name

Might be reasonable to have something like

 if options.num_containers == 1:
     options.containers = [options.container_name]
 else:
     options.containers = ['%s_%d' % (options.container_name, i)
                           for i in range(int(options.num_containers))]

It would still be a change in behavior, but I think a more-expected outcome.
i guess this is the main point of the change... it seems like we already support this option via config file?

i notice in this branch we convert options.num_containers to an int before we use it as such

OMM when I tried to test this with `num_containers = 1` in my bench.conf on my vsaio, I still got a container named `d9b155a78c3e41ccbdf2457ee55a2de8_0`

using pdb it appears this is because `options.num_containers == '1'` but `options.num_containers == 1` is False

deployment/glance/glance-api-container-p.message: Really? We want to add validations with tasks like this?

I don't think it's a good idea to pollute generated ansible playbooks with validations related to THT constructs? As discussed these should ideally be validated in tripleoclient[1] before the playbooks are generated.

Also, as GlanceApi and GlanceApiInternal go together why not add the glace_api_internal service container directly in glance-api-container-puppet.yaml rather than making it a separate service construct in THT? Are there any limitations with that?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/utils.py#L1162

Doing validations here may not be ideal, but I note some tradeoffs that seem reasonable to me. The "code" is small and concise, and covers intial deployments, updates and upgrades, as well standalone versus overcloud deployments. I looked at other validations in tripleoclient, and it looks like it would take more work/code to achieve the same result. The standalone versus overcloud deployments are different, and might require code to work out which services are on each role (something that is already handled when the playbooks are generated). I concede it would be nice if the validations could happen before the playbooks are executed, but the time delta should be small given that the validations take place in step 0.

Defining separate TripleO services let me leverage the puppet infrastructure to configure each of them appropriately (they each get their own glance-api.conf). I'm sure there are alternative approaches, but that just shifts the complexity somewhere else. The current design also made it easy to cover DCN use cases, where only the internal service is deployed at edge sites.

hi James, thanks for looking. We're actually thinking to restore [1] instead, initially proposed by Rabi so that we won't need to add validations at all. Note that the actual feature backport has been merged already [2]

1. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/866099
2. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/865885

To me, the existing code looks backwards. The logic is "GlanceAPI requires GlanceAPIInternal" correct? In that case, you need a GlanceAPIInternal resource in the GlanceAPI t-h-t template, that merges in the needed role_data keys from Internal into GlanceAPI role_data. There are numerous examples of this in t-h-t.

If you want to share things like host_prep_tasks between the 2 services so that you can still deploy Internal on its own, then you need a GlanceAPICommon that provides host_prep_tasks in its role_data, add a resource for that and merge it in the role_data. There are also examples in t-h-t.

The map_merge in role_data of GlanceAPIInternal confuses me as well. Why does GlanceAPIInternal include all of GlanceAPI's role_data, then overwrites it all? map_merge doesn't deep merge afaik? Is that just a mechanism to get the host_prep_tasks in GlanceAPIInternal?

As for the validation itself, I agree with Rabi that it is out of place and not a pattern we want across t-h-t. It belongs in tripleoclient But, given the future, you know, I probably wouldn't push too hard on that.

Hello Rajat,

Thank you very much for the review!

To make it possible to create a backup, we can provide the ability to create a clone for the attached volume and/or the ability to attach a snapshot (please see other comments).

Two existing functions: create_cloned_volume and create_volume_from_snapshot uses the same duplicate code to attach a volume and create a full copy of the source volume. So I simplified the code for create_cloned_volume:

* create_volume_from_snapshot can create a volume from snapshot
* create_cloned_volume creates a temporary snapshot and then call create_volume_from_snapshot

For some reason InfiniBox does not yet support detached clones. And if we create a clone from some parent volume, then we will not be able to delete the parent volume while it has at least one clone. And since the InfiniBox API does not support other ways to create a clone or copy of the volume, we are forced to create a full copy of the volume on the client side (attach source and destination volumes and run dd command).

Thank you!

Hello Gorka,

>>Why do we need to create a snapshot if the source is already a snapshot?  This seems to indicate that Infinidat allows attaching snapshots...

this method is implemented to perform efficient clone of a volume by driver and here we are just creating a volume from snapshot (which is a different operation) and doesn't look right at all.

I believe this is related to some storage system limitations.  The original create_cloned_volume only worked for "available" volumes because it was actually attaching the source volume and then doing dd to copy the data to the destination, so it wasn't "efficient", but it worked.

Afaik there are other drivers like qnap that do exactly this, create snapshot and then use it to create a volume and then attach this temp volume and copy it to the destination.

@Alexander: Could you confirm that Ifinidat doesn't have efficient backend cloning on the storage system?  If it doesn't, is it able to export/map snapshots so Cinder can attach them and skip the creating volume from snapshot part?

Maybe the code could skip the snapshot creation if the volume is available and only go through that path when it's attached.

Hello Gorka,

Thank you very much for the review!

>> Could you confirm that Ifinidat doesn't have efficient backend cloning on the storage system? 

Yes, I can confirm with some details: Infinidat Storage API can create an efficient clone on the storage system side, but some reason InfiniBox does not yet support detached clones. And if we create a clone from some parent volume, then we will not be able to delete the parent volume while it has at least one clone. And since the InfiniBox API does not support other ways to create a clone or copy of the volume, we are forced to create a full copy of the volume on the client side (attach source and destination volumes and run dd command). For example:

* create a volume (volume1)
* create a clone from the volume1 (volume2)
* try to delete volume1 (Cinder architecture allows us to do this)

Result:
admin@localhost> vol.create name=volume1 size=1G pool=devstack-iscsi1
Volume "volume1" created

admin@localhost> vol.clone.create vol=volume1 name=volume2 
Volume clone "volume2" created

admin@localhost> vol.delete vol=volume1
Deleting the volume 'volume1' will also delete all of its clones: volume2

So we can't use this feature and forced to create a full copy on the client side.

>> If it doesn't, is it able to export/map snapshots so Cinder can attach them and skip the creating volume from snapshot part?

Yes, thank you very much for this suggestion! Fixed in patch set #2:
Added initialize_connection_snapshot and terminate_connection_snapshot to make it possible to create a backup from a temporary snapshot. Thus, for each backup, a separate unique temporary snapshot will be created and there will be no race effect.

>> Maybe the code could skip the snapshot creation if the volume is available and only go through that path when it's attached.

I think it's safer to use a temporary snapshot in terms of data consistency.
And this approach will allow to have a common flow for creating a clone and for performing a backup.

Thank you!

inc/rootwrap.message: I think that this is o.k.-ish to get things to work fast, but IMO it needs a big fat TODO note to get cleaned up later on, since testing that projects do set up proper defaults here seems important to me in the long run.

I'm not entirely sure this needs to be cleaned up. Rootwrap requires you whitelist dirs that it will run commands out of. When we move executables into $venv/bin we have to white list those and the overlap between $PATH and what we would end up with using service defaults + $venv/bin is basically complete.

As an alternative we can append the virtualenv dirs to the defaults if we like. I just don't know that it helps.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: I think this is the answer to my question in the earlier change about why don't we just do this here instead of the periodic cleanup.
It seems most actions that could raise in _reconfigureDeletePipeline are wrapped in try blocks already and we log and ignore the errors there. Do we need to try and except here as well?

You are right in that we already handle most of the exceptions in `_reconfigureDeletePipeline()`. The main idea there was to cleanup as much as possible without stopping on the first exception. But there are still things that could fail. I'm mainly thinking about the `pipeline.state.refresh(ctx)` here.

I think in general we shouldn't abort a tenant reconfiguration by letting an exception bubble up when a step is not required to complete the reconfig. So this is more of a better-safe-than-sorry exception handling here.
Questions about safe tenant and pipeline names in the parent change would apply here as well.
See parent change for more detail, but for the moment at least, this appears to be correct for event queues.

src/charm.py.message: What are the consequences of enabling these stats? Can it negatively impact cluster performance? Why does Ceph not enable it by default?

The mgr/prometheus/rbd_stats_pools="*" was specifically introduced for Ceph dashboard some time ago so I'm not sure the question is good to be asked in this charm review. In any case, here are some references to the wildcard option:

https://github.com/ceph/ceph/commit/62986a1c3cde4262a76b37529fa865d3c036651d
https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/46034

I think that this is the perfect place for us to ask why we want to enable, by default, a feature that Ceph _explicitly_ calls out as optional. I agree that having more visibility into performance is good, but not at the cost of negatively impacting that performance so I'd like to understand why Ceph doesn't think that this should be enabled by default when they do enable so many other performance metrics.
I have updated to make the "rbd_stats_pools" configurable via charm with the same default value as ceph

Your need to rebase your change on the current master including
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ceph-dashboard/+/858874

Hmm did you have to remove the "job" part because of your changes in this patchset or has the json been broken after another patch above? I'm wondering if the "job" part needs to be fixed in more json files in general.

In any case I will retract my -1.

I have removed the "job=~\"$job\", because there will be a mismatch on the `job` name the user has selected. In this dashboard user will be able to select `job` names that are linked with ceph-mon's application name. However, this `job` name is only relevant to ceph specific metrics, that begins with `ceph_`. The generic metrics collected by telegraf will have a different job name, which is `telegraf`.

glance_store/_drivers/cinder/base.py.message: "Factory" sounds a bit too generic. Couldn't we rename this to "create_connection"?

The reason for naming this factory is because of the factory method design pattern[1] (the link also has a matching example) that instantiates a class dynamically based on the protocol used.
The same convention is used in os-brick[2] and also has the same purpose.
"create_connection" wouldn't be suitable here since it's not actually doing anything apart from instantiating the desired connector class like NFS or SCALEIO and returning to the caller.

[1] https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/factory-method-python-design-patterns/
[2] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/c9b82241eab324673147a40c494f3996d03136cd/os_brick/initiator/connector.py#L272-L277
Do we want to "pass" or should we raise UnimplementedError here?

The idea was to declare it here and the implementation is added in next patch[1] I will remove it for now to avoid confusion.
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance_store/+/868742/9/glance_store/_drivers/cinder/base.py#58
What is "f" here? A file descriptor? It's not really clear to me what the purpose of this method is, especially since the base implementation is so simple. Maybe add a docstring?

f is file object which os-brick returns and glance uses to write the image into.
The reason for implementing this method is because of the scaleio connector.
will reframe this for better readability.

Thank you folks for replying. About [1], I would keep it because:
1) This is actually fixing a problem with the ovn agent, populating some fields that we were not writing before. This is, IMO, not a new feature despite the RFE tag and the "feature" description.
2) The change is affecting the OVN database and this patch is also providing a maintenance method to health any existing OVN NB DB. So IMO this is safe to be backported. When I'm saying this is affecting the OVN database, this is not changing the structure but the data.
3) We don't change APIs, DB definitions nor config options.

So, IMO, we can keep this backport and continue with this release. In any case, and I'm the first who needs to be more careful on this, we should be more careful when backporting patches.
