New features:
* https://review.opendev.org/q/Ieb4cab11068747bd79868c6eb1778aab91447c30 is indeed a new feature. It was introduced to make the ovn-bgp-agent work and be able to filter by address scope. That is indeed a new feature and we should consider if we need to remove it.
* https://review.opendev.org/q/I50091c84e67c172c94ce9140f23235421599185c is a bug fix, an improvement for live migration in ML2/OVN. This could be between the "features" a "fixes" sections. This is a legit backport.
* https://review.opendev.org/q/I0de5fbb70eb852f82bd311616557985d1ce89bbf is a new tool to fix an existing problem is stable versions too. It introduces a config parameter that is only used by this script.
* https://review.opendev.org/q/Idfe5e51007b9a3eaa48779cd01edbca2f586eee5 is a fix too, despite we are adding a new config paramter. But the default value (True) of this parameter has no effect in the current code. If an operator doesnt' change the configuration, the behaviour will be the same.

Upgrades:
* https://review.opendev.org/q/I8bc4f2784ccefe6078506bc27cc7a98c48192ad2 it is indeed changing the default value of a config option. But in this case this is fixing an existing issue. If the deployment is using the default value set in the code, with this upgrade the number of OVN DB connections will be reduced, improving the OVN performance and reducing the OVN DB load.

Library bump:
* https://review.opendev.org/q/Ib597b62017b56b41009dd4d7359e169f424272b0: the new ovsdbapp version, previously released, is needed for this patch. It is needed due to a new class implemented. This patch is fixing the OVN NB QoS registers, adding missing fields.

swift/container/sharder.py.message: AFAICT all other stats are reported via recon dumps. That may not be *great* but is it worth remaining consistent and adding this stat the recon dump?

This metric would give us a picture of how big sharded containers are. I'd suggest using some pseudo-log scale to get better granularity e.g. 0_10, 10_50, 50_100, 100_500, 500_1000, 1000_2000 etc

But having a large number of shard ranges is not in itself 'unhealthy'. Unlike the container listing stat, where you'd like to *never* see a count of more than say 2 or 3, a single instance of this metric tells us nothing about 'health' in terms of shrinkable shards. To be useful in that respect we'd have to catch a delta, and even then I'm not sure how insightful it would be e.g. 'range_count.7000_8000 has dropped from 9 to 8 on Monday (some shrinking happened) but then went from 8 to 9 on Tuesday (some sharding happened)'.

Since we already _identify_shrinking_candidates with a count of the number of compactible_ranges, would that be a better metric to report? In fact, would it be possible to report total number of (active) shards and total number of compactible shards? Those are the exact numbers we'd like to see change when executing shrinking.

Yeah, OK maybe it isn't so useful. The problem I find is if we throw a metric we can only add it up, unless we have some more info, which is why I tried to break it up into buckets. This will be where next gen multi-label metrics could get better, we could add the account and container. 

I assume we'd always have shards, but just wanted to get an idea of how big they were getting.
But I guess that's also out of scope for now or at least trying to do it as a metric probably doesn't make sense with what we've currently got.

Maybe for now, throwing the active number into the recon with the compactible would make it better so we can see not just a downward trend when shrinking is working, but also gives us an idea of scale.

Another recon metric could be max ACTIVE shard count so we get an idea of how big things are getting, if we ever want to track it across the cluster and get bigger contianers.

TLDR, I'll pull away from throwning into statsd undil we have a better metric solution and throw into recon.

i'm worried about the number of new metrics created here

each new metric allocates a slab to store the time series data - as soon as carbon sees the first instance of a metric it creates a new ~400MB-4GB sparse file... we have billions of objects in some containers, 1B/1K ~= 1M
this might make more sense in recon as a top_n list like we do for shrinkgin/sharding candidates
yeah, great idea, top biggest makes sense.

swift/proxy/controllers/container.py.message:
I'm a little skeptical about the usefulness of this metric because it depends on the client's request pattern and parameters  i.e. the absence of high request count metrics does not tell us that we have well-balanced shard populations, it just tells us that the clients are not making listing requests that hit any poorly balanced shards.

If the metric changes, is it because the shard population balance improved, or because the clients stopped making requests that hit poorly balanced shards?

That said, I can see it could be useful as an 'alarm' if metrics with high counts do appear it is a warning that shard populations may be unbalanced. But it doesn't tell us which container. Would a warning log message be better, with a configurable threshold?

IIUC correctly the metric name will be prefixed with 'container' which is good.

I stumble over 'shard_list' because we're doing an *object* listing, and (sorry to be picky!) 'visited' is ambiguous - the loop visits potentially more shards than requests are sent to. How about calling it exactly what it is i.e. 'listing.shard_requests.%d', so with the prefix it would be:

  container.listing.shard_requests.[1, 2, 3,...]

This isn't going to cover the cases when  a backend request is made but then an exception is raised (lines 495 and 505).

Even if a refactoring results in covering those cases, the stat would be distorted because the early termination of the loop hides the fact that more backend shard range requests *would have been made* ... and if we make the leap of assuming that listings involving multiple shards (what the metric is trying to reveal) are more likely to get a bad backend response, then the metric starts to feel unreliable.

I can't see an easy way around that though. We could pre-filter the shard range list to trim it to only those that match the request param constraints (marker/end_marker/prefix) but we don't know a priori how many of the remaining will be used because we'll only actually make requests until the object count limit is reached.

yeah thy recursion that happens deeping into the call tree is cool but makes this metric (as it stands) a little inaccurate.

I like the ides of tracking how many requests were made for shards for a single get reqeust, but this obviously isn't super useful. I might shelve this metric for now. We can always so some anylytics or basically get the same kind of data from the collapsible count.

openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tes.message:
question: Why can we ignore NoSuchElementException here?
The method waits until an element specified by "locator" is visible.
What is the expected behavior if the specified element does not exist?

I know this is a backport and it is not a good place to discuss, but I would like to clarify why we can ignore this exception.

This function works only as a stabilizing time element (Tests were unstable before. Because selenium was "faster" than website). The function in default state does not affect the test. It is only smarter "wait" that does not increase duration of tests by a lot of time but slows down selenium against web => tests does not fail in situation when selenium is trying to read data that are not  loaded on the web yet.
Everything else (checking of elements/texts/states) that should or should not be on UI is not primary purpose of this function. 
It can of course be used for this purpose but it is not primary purpose.

Thanks for the clarification. It makes sense to me. This backport looks ready to go as-is.

Apart from this backport, I think it would be better to add some inline comment to note what you explained here (as L.150 above does) in the master branch. Let's discuss it separately.

nova/virt/driver.py.message: This change can affect out of tree virt driver integration. When we change this interface we tend to notify the out of tree virt driver authors via the ML. For example https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-July/015824.html Could you please drop a mail to the ML?

This was only introduced (in the tree) a couple days ago, and most drivers shouldn't need to even implement it. I only do for libvirt because of all the functional tests and it needs to be sticky.

But if it merges and you feel strongly that it's critical to do so, sure. You know my feelings on this topic :)

I'm not really afraid of out-of-tree drivers here, but my concern is more about the interface. If we really want to return a dict of key/values, then maybe the method name isn't that explicit and I'd prefer to have it clear that we return both the uuid and the name.

An alternative could be to have another virt API method for getting the nodename from an UUID, this would keep this public method unchanged.

> This was only introduced (in the tree) a couple days ago,

Then I think we don't need the mail. Thanks.

You know I introduced this method a couple patches ago right? It's been in the tree for less than a week. But if you prefer a different name, I can surely do that. The nice thing about this now is that if you only care about the uuids, you can iterate the result of this just like the list of uuids before it and you don't need to care that it's a dict.

I think making the driver maintain a (or be able to build the) mapping is going to be more work for some of them. Really, I want to remove get_available_nodes() and make this be that, but I'm trying to compartmentalize the change. Part of the problem right now is that we only talk to the RT in terms of node names, which we know are not ideal, and this gives us a single point-in-time snapshot of the mapping between the uuids and the node names.

tempest/config.py.message:
i did not find exact use case of this. once all test cases are pass and you need to check and clean the resource leakage things then you can use tempest cleanup cli.

is that satisfy the use case of running script after teardown?
the correct paste (instead of the one above) is: http://paste.openstack.org/show/718603/

Thanks for explaining the use case in very detailed way.
Re on :
Leakage of Resource  - This can be doen via 'tempest cleanup' CLI where you can check leaked resourced by running as dry run and then cleanup them.

1st point - those info still can be collected from logs where we logged all request and response. My main concern on this is - To collect such info, it required to run for every test. and It is not necessary that each test will cleanup their created resource at the end of test or during teardown. Some tests can create and delete the tests before teardown. ex - https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9c48584e0151b7aaac39751082d0f7fb108b062f/tempest/api/network/test_networks.py#L290

2nd point - not sure about it. cannot test be extended to do that or new tests to cover those external testing? If those are testing using public API endpoint then, i prefer to improve/extend the tempest test itself.

main purpose of run_on_teardown, as I would imagine, would be to troubleshoot eventual leakages problem (i.e.: to see what resources are being created during each test) rather to do the actual cleanup... a good example of using run_on_teardown which helped me troubleshoot leakage problem is shortly described at: http://paste.openstack.org/show/718597/

I'm sure leakage of resources troubleshooting is only one example of situation you may find run_on_teardown useful, other use cases would be, i.e.:
- tempest test requested creating a resource (router, instance or else) with certain properties/attributes... using run_on_teardown we can capture the actual info of the resources at the exact time of the test run and compare it to what the test originally requested to be created
- additional testing... i.e.: you run a tempest test case, you're limited only to whatever test (i.e.: asserts, ssh connectivity) such tempest test case runs to validate success/failure... using run_on_teardown you could easily employ an external system/tool to run additional tests against created resource (whether it's a router, instance or else) - could be useful (but not limited to) when using tempest on openstack deployments in NFV environment (i.e.: with SDN controllers) etc. 

NOTE: the test cases may still be successful hence using run_on_failure wouldn't be useful here at all
I hope that makes some sense
in addition, we have CONF.pause_teardown where you can insert pdb breakpoint in teardownclass and debug the things before tempest cleanup the resource.

yea, i agree on run_on failure.  this is good feature i think to collect the failure/debug info well before test cleanup the things.
we can say the log file for this case too but i agree that log files would not be sufficient on complete debugging. For example, create subnet fail due to race in quota allocation and debug script try to run that test again or something to check quota etc.
see my comments above as well as the previous general comment regarding pause_teardown - to the best of my knowledge it's not usable in CI environments

tempest/test.py.message: this way configured script will run on every test failure. how about running it at class level if any failure ?

original idea about run_on_failure was doing exactly that but I realized there may be many test cases belonging to the same test Class and running capture commands only at the class teardown time is loosing a lot of vital information

yea, even tests create and delete their own resource which you might not be able to collect if running the script on class level. So +1 on running on each failure for this use case.

Another point is what that script does cannot be specific to tests you are running. For example if you wan to collect the network resource on failure then those still runs on compute tests which might not be needed.
1. One way is to make tempest intelligent where to run configured script for example, add more info in config options or script about for what all tests failure you want to run the debug script.   
2. second way is to ask user to make script intelligent so that it recognize which service test got failed and whether you want to run the script content or not. or Script decide what to run on what type of failure. 

I think 1st one is too much magic for tempest and 2nd options looks good to me.
how about name this to run_extra_debug_script()

https://testtools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#testtools.TestCase.getDetails

Only public API methods should be used. _TestCase__details is basically a mangled variable name prefixed with __ which means that it should absolutely never be called outside the TestCase class itself.

tacker/sol_refactored/mgmt_drivers/serve.message: Why don't you call init while instantiating VnfLcmRpcApiV2? Is it not feasible?

Shimizu-san,

I'm also wondering if this locking is necessary.
Is this change caused by calling rpc.init() from VnfLcmRpcV2? (suppose not) or we have to do this whenever there're multiple instances using RPC?

> Are you mean processes can be re-initialized every single shot of rpc?
I don't mean anything. I just want to confirm what do you mean by "In other words, rpc.init() is a initialization of "rpc service", VnfLcmRpcApiV2() is a initialization of "rpc client"". What's the difference in the context of initializing rpc actually?

> In addition, there are a number of codes where rpc clients are implemented with similar policies. 
We don't have any policy that we should do implement so. It's just a result of our thoughtless of reviewing. I think changing only VnfLcmRpcApiV2 is still better and no exceptional.

I think one of the reason why we've confused is current tacker's impl is something complex. However, in rpc.init(), it's just initializing global variables such as "TRANSPORT" which is used both for server and client. In tacker, RPC server is initialized in tacker.common.rpc.get_server() [1], but this function is not called in rpc.init().

In addition, rpc.init() might not be expected directly from anywhere but we'd better to use tacker.common.config.init() instead because it looks a wrapper of rpc.init() [2].

Anyway, although I'm not sure where the get_server is called in the mgmt driver, I wonder rpc.init() here is called for the RPC client because TRANSPORT is also used in get_client() which is called in serveral functions in VnfLcmRpcV2. If so, rpc.init() should be called in VnfLcmRpcV2. What do you think?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/tacker/common/rpc.py#L206
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/tacker/common/config.py#L97

Do you say about timing of initialization? Mgmt script is executed in a independent process. I understand even if rpc was initialized for tacker-server or tacker-conductor, another initialization is needed here. VnfLcmRpcApiV2 is also instantiated at the same time here.

I don't still understand two things.
- What is the different between "rpc service" and "rpc client"?
- What is done in rpc.init()? In my understanding, it initializes three global variables, TRANSPORT, NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT and NOTIFIER, and it's enough to be done at once anywhere while initializing ServerNotificationMgmtDriver. Initializing VnfLcmRpcApiV2 is a part of ServerNotificationMgmtDriver and it's enough. Is that correct?

In PS6, it is modifyed so that rpc.init() is contained in VnfLcmRpcV2 as you suggested. So please check it again.

>Could I confirm again where rpc.init() should be called for rpc server? Or don't we need to discuss about that anymore although I don't know why the reason? Thanks.

> def init(conf):
> global TRANSPORT, NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT, NOTIFIER

I'm sorry the word "rpc server" as I said wasn't accurate. I meant each global variable have only one object in the process and should be avoided from overwriting in the uncertain timing. the "server" meant just that "it belongs to the process".

Yes, this change is caused by calling rpc.init() from VnfLcmRpcV2.
In case, if multiple VnfLcmRpcV2() are processed in thread1 and thread2,
multiple rpc.init() are also called.
In each rpc.init(), single global variable can be overwritten at the same time.
That causes trouble and that's why it need to lock.

I think there are two points to be concern when it includes rpc.init() in VnfLcmRpcV2.

(1)The first point is about race condition. As I said, VnfLcmRpcV2 can be called multiple times. If VnfLcmRpcV2 and rpc.init() are mixed,
rpc.init() can be also called multiple times in a process, TRANSPORT or NOTIFIER might be deleted and re-created at unexpected timing.
When another rpc transport in VnfLcmRpcV2 is asynchronously used at the just same time, (I think that is very rare case,) that might cause trouble.

(2)The second point is about CONF.
rpc.init() needs CONF as its parameter. that includes configuration about which driver does rpc use. I mean CONF is high level system information.
High level script(mgmt driver scrpit) should treat such content. Low level component (VnfLcmRpcV2) should not care about system information.
However, If VnfLcmRpcV2 and rpc.init() are mixed, it turns upside down. VnfLcmRpcV2 itsself reads CONF and use it for rpc.init(), That means High level script doesn't care about system information and Low level component has initiative about system configuration. I'm afraid it gets unnecessarily complex.

To avoid (1), singletone and locking must be considered in tacker/common/rpc.py.
To avoid (2), VnfLcmRpcV2 must be modified to pass config (e.g: VnfLcmRpcV2() -> VnfLcmRpcV2(CONF))
However, my current implementation is not affected by these points.

> My suggestion is to move this two lines into initialization in `VnfLcmRpcApiV2` 

I would like to know why you want to move these lines.

I try to improve rpc.py and conductor_rpc_v2.py. But it needs a while for implimentation and testing.

Sorry, I don't get your point. What do you mean by consistency? In these example you mentioned, it just defining its init() and calling tacker.common.rpc.init(), and it's just a little bit different from your update.

I also not sure what do you mean by "additional init()". I've just suggested to call it in initialization in VnfLcmRpcApiV2 instead of here.

I'm afraid your suggestion could not keep consistency with the other codes that use rpc. It affects tacker-server or tacker-conductor. They already initialize rpc in
tacker/common/config.py, tacker/conductor/conductor_server.py. Additional init() may causes trouble.

I don't mean so. In your update, there are two `ServerNotificationMgmtDriver` doing the same rpc.init(). My suggestion is to move this two lines into initialization in `VnfLcmRpcApiV2` which is called in the next line as you mentioned. Is it not feasible?

Thank you for your question, I would like to explain more.
> - What is the different between "rpc service" and "rpc client"?
"rpc service" is a part of process starting. "rpc client" is used for transporting. Are you mean processes can be re-initialized every single shot of rpc? 
> - What is done in rpc.init()? In my understanding, it initializes three global variables, TRANSPORT, NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT and NOTIFIER
Yes, that's right. These values decide where rpc can transport message. If rpc client itsself decides these values as your suggestion, versatility is decreased. (As if a http client that cannot specify addresses.)
In addition, there are a number of codes where rpc clients are implemented with similar policies. (tacker/conductor/conductorrpc/vnf_lcm_rpc.py, vnfpkgmrpc.py)
Is only VnfLcmRpcApiV2 exceptionally changed?

I'm sorry I didn't explain it enough. In other words, rpc.init() is a initialization of "rpc service", VnfLcmRpcApiV2() is a initialization of "rpc client". Multiple rpc clients can be created. However, rpc service must be create only once in a process. So VnfLcmRpcApiV2 should not include rpc.init().

Thank you for your comment.

"rpc service" is a function of oslo_messaging. (https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/reference/server.html)
and "rpc client" is also a function of oslo_messaging.
(https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/reference/rpcclient.html)

VnfLcmRpcApiV2 is used for controlling rpc client.
rpc.init() is used for controlling rpc server.
I'd like to avoid mixing them.

the difference between them is its lifecycle.

the lifecycle of rpc server is
1-1. start process
1-2. start rpc server on the process
1-3. rpc service is enabled until the end of process.

the lifecycle of rpc client is
2-1. create oslo_messaging.RPCClient when process need to send RPC
2-2. send RCP.
2-3. delete RPCClient.
2-4. re-create oslo_messaging.RPCClient when process need to send another RPC
2-5. send RCP.
2-6. delete RPCClient.

If they are mixed, I can't keep each lifecycle.

I don't strongly think we should rpc init in VnfLcmRpcV2, but not clear where it should be done.

> I would like to know why you want to move these lines.
It's just I thought it's no need to add rpc.init() in all mgmt driver if it's added into VnfLcmRpcV2. No other reasons. So, you can surely reject my comment if there is a reason to do so. It's welcome for me.

For (1), I'm not sure where the race condition is happened. If such a case can be happened, we should add some lock mechanism to avoid the race as you mentioned even if we implement rpc.init in . correct?

For (2), I think it cannot be a strong reason so that because we don't have any agreement what is high level or low level for CONF among our team.

Could I confirm again where rpc.init() should be called for rpc server? Or don't we need to discuss about that anymore although I don't know why the reason? Thanks.

Thanks Facundo for your review.

I've changed this patch to have a single configuration named "haproxy-check-http-config" as you pointed in the review.

Could you also review the change on charm-layer-openstack that is dependent on this change?

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-layer-openstack/+/862752

Thanks

This pr is targeted against reactive charms and is seems to provide an inconsistent approach with the corresponding classic charm change.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-glance/+/862521

I think the classic charm approach of not exposing new charm config options feels like the right approach as the charm should know how to check the health of the payload.

If you decide to follow the classic charm pattern I *think* you could have the charm class specify a dict like:

```
class DesignateCharm(ch_plugins.PolicydOverridePlugin,
                     openstack_charm.HAOpenStackCharm):
    ....
    healthcheck = {
        'option': 'httpchk GET /healthcheck',
        'http-check': 'expect status 200',
```

The APIConfigurationAdapter *1 has access to an instance of the charm class so it could read that dict and set it as a property which can then be referenced by the PeerHARelationAdapter via self.api_config_adapter.

*1 https://opendev.org/openstack/charms.openstack/src/branch/master/charms_openstack/adapters.py#L726

As with the classic charm example I am not convinced this is going to work when the endpoints are using TLS.

For future reference I think this work would have benefited from a spec.

config.yaml.message: Given that there are several other checks supported by haproxy (I see mysql, psql, external, ldap, etc.), what about changing the name of the property to "haproxy-http-check-expected"?

I see on haproxy's docs that checks can be relatively smart, including an http-check connect and one or more http-check send plus expect statements.

Having two config properties one for the request and one for the expect prevents the use of these more complex check constructs from being configurable through the charm (or at least makes it a bit hacky, as perhaps one of the two could be used to set a multi-line value and get away with it?).

So how about having an single haproxy-check-config property? As an example, its default could be what's on the code at the time of writting this comment: "http-check send meth GET uri /healthcheck\nhttp-check expect status 200".

Yes, it makes sense. In a rollback/downgrade scenario, this commit will sync the rpm of the version performing the operation and will work fine.

Sorry, the correct is stx6 to stx8 upgrade.

Taking a second look on the commit I think it will work fine, but please test the upgrade to confirm and update the test plan accordingly.

I performed the upgrade tests. I had no errors in the procedure. Anyway, the STX 6 rpm packages were not synced with /var/www/pages/updates. This happens because the code is looking for the current system version in /etc/build.info (stx8 after the upgrade), so it makes the rsync only for this version folder and ignores the possible old version folders (stx6).

If we want to sync all version folders from opt/patching/updates to www/pages/updates, it will be necessary to make some code changes, otherwise, only the new version will be synced (and it will probably always be empty because it's a new version/install in upgrade cases).

setup.cfg.message:
These are backwards. The structure should be:

  <object> <action>

from [1]. We also don't use the term 'get' because it's ambiguous. You use either 'show' (for a single resource) or 'list' (for multiple resources). I assume you want 'list' here? Finally, we use the 'block storage' term to disambiguate between things that affect a 'volume' and things that affect the volume/block storage service. The 'volume service *' predate this convention and should really be migrated, but we probably don't want to add new commands that confuse this. Taken together, these should probably be:

  block storage log set
  block storage log list

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/contributor/humaninterfaceguide.html#objects-and-actions

zuul/model.py.message: What's the reason we are copying the versions dict here? Shouldn't it be fine to update the build version directly and pass it to `updateAttributes()`?

This was so that if there is an exception, we won't have updated our internal object, so it will behave more like when we call updateAttributes with a scalar.  I don't know if it's necessary, but it seemed safer and more predictable.
Changed in a followup so we can treat this question independently.

I think this (update before save to ZK) is already the case when using the `activeContext()` ctx manager.

Having the copy adds a little more object churn, but I guess this is more of a nit.
True, we really have two different behaviors.  I don't feel strongly about keeping it this way.

If we did a != comparison would that give us the flexibility to write buildsets, jobs, and builds in any order? I've tried to trace through some of the state transitions here and I think this is correct, but it seems to rely on very careful order of operations and resource access. For example you must always read the buildset first before accessing builds or jobs otherwise another executor may have updated the builds/jobs but youwould think you are up to date.

Semi related, we default to expected = 0 and current = -1 if we haven't done the initial write to Zookeeper yet? This seems too be necessary to carefully ensure the behavior we need. Is that worth at least a comment that the two default values need to keep this ordered relationship? Or maybe drop the default 0 value and always refresh if expected is None?

We do read in exactly the right order since this is in the (de)serialize methods, which are called on the top-most ZK object and work their way down (or up) in the order you specified.  So I don't think it's fragile, and reading in any other order is very much invalid (we might consider panicking if expected < current).

But in general, an ordered comparison on a "version" number seems natural to me.

I found this approach of creating a single staging folder, packaging for armada, removing some things, adding other and packaging again to fluxcd a little too confusing. I also requested this on [0] but I was overruled by the cores, but I maintain my request here so we strive to increase the quality and clarity on all Stx projects.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: New patchset incoming

@Matt I think the principle of this change is right, but I'd like to explore moving away from the confusing semantics of get_own_shard_range - see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/852283 (only had time to push up a quick WIP, but could be a base for this change if we like it)

@Matt - I started looking at this again, and ending up hacking some tests to help me understand https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/867038/1

Took me a while to remember that this patch alone does not solve the underpopulated cleaved shard problem, because the sharder still sets actual object stats when a shard reaches CLEAVED - we need the next patch to fix that. But this patch lays the ground for off-whack stats being reported before CLEAVED (which is perhaps an existing bug/non-feature in itself), which my probe test change demonstrates.

This change makes sense to me - I think it fixes a window of anomalous stats reporting which is in itself a good thing, and needed to be corrected before we can work more on the transition to CLEAVING.

I think it's worth a little more polishing - see comments and diff. Thanks Matt!

swift/container/backend.py.message:
Might be worth spelling these all out, like we did for SHARD_AUDITING_STATES. Not sure whether it was the double-hop of SHARD_STATS_STATES -> SHARD_LISTING_STATES -> SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES, the distance from the other definitions, or just my own tiredness, but it took me several read-throughs to see that this included SHARDING and SHRINKING.

The thrust of it is, "everything except FOUND and CREATED", right? And even FOUND is only sort of excluded, since there should never be an actual DB in FOUND state, right?

Yeah, I can understand that, and it is getting a little unwieldy. Specifying it fully probably is a better and easier maintainable way. When the other "states" dont really releate the update_stats. Will change.
I don't think we even know the byte count from the found shard ranges, correct?

correct, we are only going on object count. Because we are basically sharding the object list, where byte count isn't important, at least from the sharding POV.

I guess we could start tracking it, it may give us some new features. But when finding the shards we tend to jump to the next upper so we don't have to process each row. So doesn't really make sense when finding ranges, unless in the future we decide to shard on amount of space they take up on the object server side of things, which would more be a placement thing not a sharding object metadata thing. In anycase I think out of scope of this change.

We don't actually pull in the byte-count for each range we keep them 0. But its the object count that we use for sharding and is_deleted checks so needs to remain. Once the range is CLEAVED it should have a more accurate bytes_count, so I think it's all ok.
Off-topic: "constant" isn't quite right, but I'm not sure how better to put it. At any rate, we don't want it flapping about wildly.
representative? consistent? I'll pick something else :)
nit: "a", and s/the size of/of the size/

I've never really liked the way the stats are updated as a side effect (but not persisted) and it feels like this is getting more convoluted i.e. the side effect is now conditional, and depends on what feels more like sharding state than DB state. I wonder if the time has come to separate out the stats updating? 

I took a crack at it here https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/852283
I like additional commentary to help us remember the *whys* of sharder behaviour! :)

maybe add a comment

  # shard's may not be fully populated while in the FOUND and CREATED
  # state, so shards should only update their own shard range's object 
  # stats when they are in the following states
Well, an iterator of dicts, anyway -- I think I'd be a fan of pulling them into a list later, though.

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
I guess moving this into here changes what the old patch did. Previously the stats wouldn't change in the DB unless the range had been reported. Now it's changing on every cycle but not actually always updating the root.

Maybe I should pull 2262 back out and down to line 2261. 
But by moving it into the if-block means it'll only merge and write it out when something had changed (updated stats, relcaim, etc). :shrug:

I don't understand this statement "Now it's changing on every cycle but not actually always updating the root." If the own_sr stats are changed by the call to update_own_shard_range_stats then won't own_shard_range.reported be False at line 2277?
yup your right. if the stats do get updated the reported is turned to False.
IDK, might it be ok to just list FOUND and CREATED?

oh you hean if it's not in FOUND and CREATED because the the otherway of saying it.. yeah that's true. But as it currently is more readable and hopefully maintainable.

Though happy to be convinced the otherway.
it works either way, no big deal

slightly off topic: I was wondering why we don't just roll the tombstone stats update into update_own_shard_range_stats, but remembered that this is the only place we care about up to date tombstone count i.e. when we're about to send stats to the root - might be worth adding a comment to that effect.

(shrinking candidates are found in the root DB so that's the only place we need up to date tombstone stats)

note to self: we cannot simply write, earlier,

  if own_shard_range.state not in SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES:
      return
      
because:

1. this may be the first pass over a new shard DB so the initial own shard range has not been reported to root before: we do still want to let the root know about new shard ranges, even if we don't want them to report their dynamic stats yet.

2. hypothetical: the shard was in SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES, updated its stats, but the PUT to root failed. The shard is now not in SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES but the latest stats have not been reported. Hypothetical because we do not expect shard state to revert from being in SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES to not being in SHARD_UPDATE_STAT_STATES.
yeah, I think its just safer to use the .reported as latching is its job anyway.

this is odd: meta_timestamp is always set even when the stats are not updated? I think that is because we *do* still update the tombstones count, which is not consistent with not updating the object count. But I'm also concerned that we're setting meta_timestamp to now but for a stale value of object_count.
